childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1992-2004

Children born in 1992 arrived during a year of fracture. The LA riots — sparked by the Rodney King verdict, fueled by decades of racial injustice and economic neglect — killed fifty-five people and caused a billion dollars in damage. Bill Clinton won the presidency on a promise of change. The first World Trade Center bombing would happen before this cohort's first birthday. America in 1992 was simultaneously optimistic about its future and combusting over its present, and the babies being born that spring were oblivious to both.

Their conscious childhood began in the mid-1990s, during what would later be remembered as one of the most stable periods in recent American history. The economy was booming. Unemployment was falling. The stock market was climbing at a pace that made financial advisors nervous and everyone else giddy. Their parents — Boomers and early Gen Xers — were buying houses, refinancing mortgages, talking about college savings at the dinner table. The domestic atmosphere was shaped by a prosperity that felt earned and permanent, even though it was neither.

The school experience for this cohort straddled two technological eras with disorienting speed. Their early elementary classrooms still had chalkboards, pull-down maps, and overhead projectors — the analog infrastructure of American education, largely unchanged since the 1960s. By the time they reached middle school, computer labs were standard, the internet was being used for homework, and keyboarding was a scheduled class. They learned cursive and they learned to type, within a few years of each other, without anyone explaining that one of these skills was about to become decorative.

The neighborhood dynamics of their childhood showed a country growing increasingly protective of its young. By the late 1990s, the free-range childhood that earlier cohorts had experienced — disappearing after breakfast, returning at dark — was giving way to a more supervised model. Not everywhere, not all at once, but the trend was clear. More structured activities. More parental involvement in play. More awareness, driven largely by cable news, of the things that could go wrong. This cohort's parents loved them in a way that expressed itself as vigilance, and the children grew up with the sense that the world outside the front door required more caution than it used to.

At seven, Columbine happened. This cohort was in second grade — young enough to be shielded from the worst details, old enough to feel the reverberations. The school assemblies. The new rules about what couldn't be brought to school. The drills that taught them to crouch silently in dark classrooms and wait for an all-clear that might not come. For children born in 1992, the school shooting wasn't an abstract news event — it was the reason their school day now included practicing for the worst.

At nine, September 11 happened. Third or fourth grade. They watched the towers fall on classroom televisions, or were picked up early by parents who drove too fast and held them too tight. The event was comprehensible enough to be terrifying and incomprehensible enough to be permanently unsettling. The Iraq War began when they were eleven. By the time they reached middle school, America had been at war for their entire conscious memory of current events. War wasn't an interruption of normal life — it was normal life. The flags, the troop deployments, the evening news casualties — all of it woven into the fabric of a childhood that had started in peace and ended in a conflict with no visible end point.

generational_identity.html:
The Millennial Generation

Millennials, born between 1981 and 1996 according to Pew Research, which finally settled the boundary debate after years of arguing. This generation numbers about 72 million Americans, which made them the largest cohort until Gen Z started catching up. This generation grew up being told they were special, that they could be anything, that the world was waiting for them. Then they graduated into a crater.

The defining moment for Millennials was 9/11. This cohort was {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}}—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. Old enough to watch the towers fall, young enough to have their entire worldview shaped by the aftermath rather than disrupted by it. Security checkpoints, forever wars, color-coded terror alerts—that became their normal. The pre-9/11 world is a foreign country they barely remember, glimpsed in old movies where people walk friends to airport gates.

This generation graduated into either the Great Recession itself or its long toxic aftermath. If they went straight to work, they hit the worst job market since the Depression. If they went to college, they graduated into a crater. Entry-level jobs required three years of experience. Unpaid internships were sold as 'opportunities.' The gig economy wasn't freedom—it was desperation rebranded with app notifications and contractor status.

This generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. This generation gets blamed for killing industries, demanding participation trophies, and being simultaneously too optimistic and too pessimistic. In reality, they just graduated into the worst economy since their great-grandparents, watched housing prices triple while wages stagnated, and got told their struggle was a character flaw instead of a policy failure. They didn't kill Applebee's—they couldn't afford it.

Millennials are the bridge generation. They remember life before smartphones but can't imagine life without them now. They're digital natives who know what dial-up sounds like. They're nostalgic for a past they barely experienced and anxious about a future that keeps getting worse. They contain contradictions because their era does.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The year 1992 brought Unforgiven winning Best Picture and Clint Eastwood reminding everyone he could still act while deconstructing the Western mythology that made him famous. Disney released Aladdin with Robin Williams improvising as the Genie. Wayne's World brought SNL sketches to theaters and taught everyone to say 'Schwing!' and 'Party on!' without irony. Sister Act put Whoopi Goldberg in a nun's habit, which somehow worked.

Musically, 1992 was grunge's coronation. Nirvana's Nevermind went platinum, and suddenly flannel and angst were mainstream. Pearl Jam and Soundgarden were everywhere. Dr. Dre dropped The Chronic and changed hip-hop forever with G-funk production and Snoop Dogg's introduction. Whitney Houston's 'I Will Always Love You' dominated radio for what felt like an entire year. Boyz II Men made everyone slow dance at middle school prom to songs about heartbreak they didn't understand yet.

Television in 1992 was transforming. The Real World invented reality TV—seven strangers in a house, cameras everywhere, conflicts manufactured or real depending on cynicism level. MTV still played music videos. Cartoon Network launched, giving this cohort a dedicated channel for animation that would babysit their entire generation. The Tonight Show was still Johnny Carson's, but not for long.

This childhood was Rugrats, Hey Arnold!, and Pokémon arriving like a cultural invasion they couldn't resist. Middle school years belonged to TRL, boy bands versus girl groups, Britney versus Christina debates that felt genuinely important. High school brought emo, MySpace profiles with carefully curated auto-playing songs, and the early YouTube era when viral videos were still surprising rather than algorithmic.

The pop culture absorbed was pre-algorithm. Ads couldn't be skipped—they were endured. Shows couldn't be binged—waiting a week between episodes and discussing theories with friends at school. Music came on physical CDs bought at Best Buy or downloaded illegally on Napster. Movies actually went to theaters to see. Culture was something experienced on its schedule, not one's own.

technology.html:
Technology Timeline

The year 1992 brought the first smartphone prototype—IBM's Simon, a brick-sized device that nobody bought but that predicted everything that came later. It had a touchscreen, email, apps. It cost $900 and sold 50,000 units. Thirty years later, everyone would carry something a thousand times more powerful and consider it indispensable.

The World Wide Web existed in 1992 but wasn't public yet. Most people had never heard the word 'internet.' Personal computers were expensive beige boxes that ran DOS commands nobody understood. Windows 3.1 launched that year, which made PCs slightly less terrifying for normal people. The first text message was sent in December: 'Merry Christmas.' The idea that everyone would communicate primarily through text was science fiction.

Windows 95 came out when this cohort was three, complete with the Rolling Stones song and lines around the block at computer stores. Google launched when they were six—lowercase, minimalist, promising not to be evil. The first iPod arrived when they were twelve, a thousand songs in a pocket. Facebook opened to high schools when they were fourteen. The iPhone dropped when they were fifteen, and everything before it instantly looked prehistoric.

This cohort didn't grow up with smartphones—they watched them colonize everything in real-time, year by year, feature by feature. This makes them part of the last generation to remember life before the internet was mandatory. They know what boredom felt like before screens filled every empty moment. They printed MapQuest directions. They used a card catalog at the library. They can explain dial-up noises to younger people who don't believe them.

This generation's relationship with technology is complicated in ways that pure digital natives don't experience. They can troubleshoot both their parents' WiFi and their grandparents' VCR. They've watched social media go from fun to mandatory to exhausting to genuinely concerning. They understand that convenience comes at a cost—they just accepted the terms and conditions without reading them, like everyone else.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The year 1992 brought the LA riots—four days of chaos after the Rodney King verdict acquitted officers filmed beating a Black man on the ground. America's racial tensions exploded on live television. Fifty-five people died. A billion dollars in property destroyed. It was the first major civil unrest this cohort existed during, though they'd have to learn what it meant later. Similar footage would return throughout their lives, proving that some things didn't change.

This cohort was one when the World Trade Center was bombed the first time—a truck full of explosives in the parking garage, six dead, a thousand injured. It was supposed to collapse the towers. It didn't. Eight years before the second, successful attempt that would define this generation.

This cohort was three when the Oklahoma City bombing happened—168 dead, including 19 children in a daycare. Domestic terrorism before anyone used that phrase commonly. They were six when Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel, and the global mourning taught them that collective grief was a spectacle now, performed on television for billions.

This cohort was seven when Columbine happened. School shootings existed before, but Columbine created the template—the rolling coverage, the blame games, the copycat fear. This cohort probably had their first lockdown drill before fifth grade. Schools became places where they practiced hiding, not just learning.

This cohort was nine during 9/11. They watched the towers fall, possibly in a classroom, possibly at home with parents who didn't know what to say. Teachers crying. Adults looking scared in ways they'd never seen. The world split into before and after that morning. Everything that followed—the wars, the surveillance, the fear—happened during their formative years.

This cohort was fifteen during the 2008 financial crisis. Old enough to understand something terrible was happening, young enough to inherit all the consequences. College costs were skyrocketing. Jobs were disappearing. The economy they graduated into was a wasteland dressed up in recovery statistics.

By their early twenties, Occupy Wall Street articulated what everyone felt but couldn't name. By their mid-twenties, marriage equality was legal and Trump announced his campaign. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world—killing over a million Americans. History kept happening, faster and worse than anyone expected. This generation has lived through more 'unprecedented' events than any generation since the Greatest Generation.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

College graduation around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}} meant entering the aftermath of the 2008 financial crisis. If this cohort went straight to work after high school, they hit the worst job market in eighty years. If they went to college, they graduated into wreckage. The job market was 'recovering,' which meant it existed again, not that it worked. Entry-level positions required years of experience. 'Networking' became a verb used constantly but hated viscerally.

This generation normalized the 'side hustle' because one income stream wasn't enough. Driving for Uber, selling things on Etsy, monetizing hobbies that previous generations did for fun. The gig economy wasn't liberation—it was survival dressed up in startup language and contractor forms. They became entrepreneurs, which is what people call someone without benefits.

The workplace transformed. Open offices replaced cubicles, which had replaced private offices. Standing desks appeared. Then everyone got back problems. Kombucha showed up in break room fridges alongside ping pong tables and 'unlimited PTO' policies that nobody actually used because the culture punished time off.

This is the generation that normalized job-hopping. Not because they're disloyal, but because companies stopped being loyal first. The implicit contract—work hard, get rewarded, stay for decades, retire with a pension—was already dead by the time they arrived. They learned to chase raises by leaving, not staying. Two years became a long tenure. Five became unusual. Ten became suspicious.

COVID reshaped everything when this cohort was in their late twenties. Remote work went from rare perk to standard practice. They proved they could be productive from home, which means employers now expect them to be productive from everywhere, all the time. The boundary between work and life dissolved. Laptops became coworkers they couldn't escape, pinging at midnight, lurking during dinner.

This generation has been told to 'follow passion' while watching passionate people burn out. They've been told to 'hustle' by people who inherited their positions. They've been told the economy is recovering while rent takes more of their paycheck every year. The career advice they received was written for a world that no longer exists.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

This generation grew up with dating apps but still remembers meeting people in person. Tinder launched when they were about twenty-one. By the time they were actively dating as an adult, swiping was standard practice. Romance became a sorting algorithm they couldn't opt out of if they wanted to participate.

This cohort probably met at least one significant partner online, which parents find mildly concerning and younger siblings find completely unremarkable. They're the bridge generation—old enough to remember asking someone out face-to-face with voice shaking, young enough to have normalized doing it through screens where rejection is just silence.

Communication style evolved with the platforms. Starting with AIM away messages that were really just poetry for a crush. Graduating to Facebook wall posts, migrating to texting, and now maintaining relationships through a rotating cast of apps. Remembering when calling someone was normal. Now it's suspicious. 'Why is someone calling? Is someone dead?'

This generation delayed marriage, cohabitation, and children longer than any before. Not because they don't want these things, but because weddings cost $30,000, houses cost half a million, and childcare costs more than college tuition. The life script their parents followed isn't available at a price they can afford. They're not commitment-phobic—they're priced out.

Friendships maintained across geographic distance via group chats, social media, and occasional reunions. Watching friend groups fragment as people moved for jobs, partners, or cheaper cities. Knowing how to feel close to people rarely seen in person and distant from people who live next door. Connection became asynchronous, which is both freeing and lonely.

This generation has normalized therapy and talking about mental health in relationships. Previous generations suffered in silence. This generation suffers out loud, which is marginally better. They've learned that relationships require 'work,' which nobody told their grandparents, who just stayed married because divorce was expensive and embarrassing.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

The dot-com bubble burst when this cohort was eight—something that happened to adults, not to them, but they absorbed the anxiety. Sixteen during the 2008 financial crisis, watching parents worry about jobs and retirement accounts. Twenty-eight during COVID's economic collapse. This generation has watched the economy implode three times before turning thirty-five. Their financial worldview is best described as 'waiting for the next crash while hoping to outrun it.'

The relationship with money is defined by never having quite enough. Student loans followed them into adulthood. Housing prices climbed faster than their income could possibly match. The gap between where they are and where they were promised they'd be grows wider every year despite doing everything right.

Saving compulsively because they've seen stability evaporate overnight. Investing reluctantly, distrustful of markets that seem designed to extract wealth from people like them and transfer it to people unlike them. Playing the game because opting out means losing by default. At least playing gives them a chance.

This generation has been lectured about spending habits by people who bought houses when they cost two years' salary. The median home price in 1992 was around $100,000. Now it's over $400,000 in most markets, much higher in cities with jobs. Wages have roughly doubled. Housing has quadrupled. The math doesn't work, and everyone who did the math when it worked keeps telling them to try harder.

This generation is redefining success because the old definitions are unattainable. It's not owning property—it's finding an apartment they can afford in a city with jobs. It's not retiring at 65—it's hoping to retire at all. It's not building wealth for their children—it's hoping they won't burden them with their care. The goalposts moved. Nobody told them. They figured it out when they arrived and found an empty field.

This generation has watched cryptocurrency boom, crash, boom, and crash again. They've watched housing prices defy gravity and logic. They've watched inflation eat their raises. The rules of financial success keep changing, written by people who already won and revised to ensure they can't follow the same path.

blind_spots.html:
Generational Blind Spots

This generation's greatest strength is also its trap: they believe in self-improvement as salvation. Tracking everything—sleep scores, step counts, screen time, meditation streaks. Approaching personal growth like an engineering problem, optimizing themselves toward a happiness that keeps receding as they approach. The problem is some things can't be optimized. Systemic failure doesn't respond to better habits.

This generation is so skilled at adapting to dysfunction that they sometimes forget to challenge it. They've normalized precarious employment, unaffordable housing, healthcare tied to jobs they can lose at any moment. They've learned to survive broken systems instead of demanding they be fixed. Resilience became resignation somewhere along the way.

This generation is conflict-averse in ways that cost them. They've been trained to be collaborative, agreeable, and professional—which often means accepting less than they deserve because making demands feels uncomfortable. They'll take 'exposure' instead of payment. They'll absorb extra work without extra compensation. They'll stay in bad situations because leaving feels worse than staying until it doesn't.

This generation is so steeped in irony that earnestness feels risky. They can't just care about something—they have to care about it ironically, or care while acknowledging the absurdity of caring, or care while pre-emptively mocking themselves for caring. This makes advocating for themselves surprisingly difficult. Their defensive armor is also their prison.

This generation is chronically online in ways that sometimes substitute for offline action. They can organize on social media, but voter turnout in local elections is dismal. They can cancel celebrities, but changing laws requires showing up to boring meetings. The dopamine hit of digital activism feels like progress even when it isn't. Engagement metrics aren't the same as power.

This generation has been told they're special so many times that ordinary feels like failure. Their parents said they could be anything. Childhood participation trophies told them everyone wins. Reality told them something different, and the gap between expectation and outcome fuels much of their anxiety. Ordinary is fine. Nobody told them that growing up.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

The 20s (2012-2022): Graduating into an economy still recovering from 2008—'recovering' meaning corporations were posting profits again, not that jobs paid living wages. Taking positions beneath qualifications because something was better than nothing. Living with roommates or parents longer than planned. Watching rent consume more of income every year while wages barely moved. This was supposed to be the decade of exploration and growth. Instead, it was about survival and adaptation, putting out fires rather than building foundations. Ending it in a pandemic, which felt about right.

The 30s (2022-2032): This decade now. Probably earning more than the twenties but still not enough for the life promised. Watching Gen Z enter the workforce with different expectations and older generations finally retire with resources they'll never accumulate. This is supposedly the 'settling down' period, but settling requires stability they don't have. Building a life on foundations that keep shifting. If wanting kids, the biological and financial clocks are both ticking louder.

The 40s (2032-2042): Statistically, this will be the peak earning decade. More authority, more clarity, more acceptance of what can't be changed. Parents will be elderly, bringing new responsibilities and costs. Possibly managing aging parents, children, and career demands simultaneously—the sandwich generation in full effect. This is when one either doubles down on what's been built or burns it down and starts fresh. Most people do a little of both.

The 50s (2042-2052): By now, having survived multiple economic crises, at least one pandemic, and countless 'unprecedented' events that happen every few years now. Close to traditional retirement age but unlikely to retire traditionally. Mentoring younger colleagues who don't understand why they're so cautious, so scarred, so obsessed with emergency funds. Annoyed at their optimism and jealous of it simultaneously.

The 60s and beyond (2052+): Retirement, if it happens, will look nothing like parents' version. Part-time work, gig economy participation, or reliance on family are all likely scenarios. Social Security's future is uncertain. Climate change will have reshaped geography and economics in ways nobody can fully predict. The world will be unrecognizable from the one this generation was born into. Telling younger people about landlines, Blockbuster, and life before smartphones. They'll think it's exaggerating. It won't be.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year. This cohort is part of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): More educated, more diverse, and significantly less wealthy at the same age. Gen X inherited a functioning economy and watched it break. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing. Gen X got affordable college—this generation got student loans that follow them for decades. Gen X got pensions—this generation got 401(k)s with fees that eat gains. Gen X got starter homes—this generation got starter apartments they can barely afford in cities with jobs.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were this age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. This generation controls 7%. Boomers bought houses for two or three years' salary, often on single incomes. This generation is spending that on rent. Boomers expected pensions and Social Security. This generation expects neither to exist in recognizable form by the time they need them.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): Similar but slightly more bruised by disappointment. This generation remembers when things felt possible, when optimism seemed reasonable. Gen Z doesn't have that baseline—they arrived after hope left. This generation believed the system could work if fixed. Gen Z assumes it's broken beyond repair and builds workarounds. This generation adapted to smartphones arriving in their teens. Gen Z doesn't remember before. This generation is the last with clear memories of the before times.

Life expectancy is 78-80 years, slightly lower than previous generations. This generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before. More anxious, more depressed, more medicated. The world they inherited is harder, and it shows in the numbers.

But this generation is also more tolerant, more educated, and more aware of systemic problems than any generation before. They've normalized mental health treatment. They've pushed for workplace equity. They've demanded that institutions acknowledge problems they used to ignore. This generation inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. That matters, even if it doesn't pay the rent.

year_events: LA riots erupted after the Rodney King verdict
Mall of America opened as largest US mall
The Real World premiered on MTV
